0.text: MATT PARKER: Today I'm gonna show you a... amazing number,

2.text: and some of you may have come across this before.

3.text: It's an absolute classic, but I still think there's a lot to be said about the number

16.text: ...four, nine --this is where it gets quite interesting actually,

21.text: ...three, eight, zero, nine, six, --you'll notice, actually, this is one of the more boring parts of the number--

29.text: Every time I mess this bit up, hang on, that...

32.text: that bit shouldn't be there; I put that in by accident.

39.text: And there it is; that's the number I'm going to talk about today.

43.text: I still find this number absolutely fascinating,

47.text: and the reason this number is so great is because it relates to a fantastic inequality.

52.text: A formula if you will, which I will put underneath here.

56.text: So, the formula we're gonna look at is:

58.text: ½ less than the floor function of the mod function of

65.text: the floor function of the y-coordinate on 17,

71.text: —floor function— times 2 to the power of negative 17 times the floor function of x

77.text: subtract the mod of the floor function of y again.

85.text: And that is mod 17, so I close that mod there

90.text: and then this whole thing, once you've got that,

93.text: you then -- that open mod is 2; close that, and then close the floor function.

99.text: OK, so now we have ridiculous number and we have ridiculous equation.

103.text: To show you how the two are linked, I thought I would show you the plot of this inequality,

107.text: because what they're saying is: if you have an x,y axis

111.text: and you put—for each point on that plane—you put in the x- and y-coordinates into this formula,

117.text: it would tell you whether or not you should colour in that point.

120.text: So, in fact, this tells you which part of an x,y plot should have a dot, and which shouldn't.

126.text: And I've got a printout I have done of that formula,

129.text: and, so, if you plot that formula, you get this plot here.

133.text: So, this is the plot of that formula, and,

137.text: in case you're wondering what is particularly astounding about this,

140.text: the formula, when you plot it, is itself.

145.text: The formula is its own plot. The plot is the formula.

148.text: This is called Tupper's self-referential formula,

150.text: and when you plot it, you get itself,

153.text: and that, for me, is one of the freakiest, most bizarre parts of mathematics.

158.text: A formula which is its own plot.

160.text: Okay, there is, however, one slight cheat

164.text: it does-- it actually does that; if you plot this formula, you get itself

168.text: as its plot, but the cheat is this 'k' down here,

172.text: because I haven't actually specified where we are on the vertical y-axis.

176.text: You can see on the x-axis we're zero to 106; fairly normal territory.

180.text: But here we're like "'k', what on earth is that?"

183.text: That k value is this number here.

186.text: Basically, we are a long way up the y-axis right now.

189.text: If you go a huge distance up the y-axis of this plot,

192.text: and you ignore everything else below it, and there's more after it; ignore everything above it.

196.text: At this one particular zone between this number and this number plus 17,

202.text: is where you get the equation that we were using to plot them.

206.text: What's actually amazing about Tupper's self-referential formula

209.text: is not that it plots itself — it's that it plots everything.

212.text: As you go up the y-axis, it plots every single 106x17 grid of white and black pixels.

220.text: So, anything that fits in that grid is somewhere on this plot.

223.text: So, not only is Tupper's formula in the plot,

226.text: but also every other formula you can fit into that size.

229.text: In fact, I found a different value of k which is where it's the same formula, but smiley faces instead of the word 'mod'.

237.text: And so, that's a slightly different value of k, gives you the smiley-face version of this formula.

242.text: Also found the point where Pac-Man is eating the formula, as chased by a ghost.

248.text: And so, that one is... I think that one's gonna be higher up as well

252.text: It's... yes. It's not far off, though.

255.text: And so, anything you can possibly fit into one of these appears in there somewhere.

260.text: And I can actually show you how you can get from any picture you want to that number.

264.text: The way it actually works is you take the pixelated form of your equation,

268.text: so let's get our original one.

270.text: Let's do... Where's the proper one? None of these ridiculous ones.

273.text: Okay, here were go, right. So there's...there's the original one.

275.text: And what you do is you start in the bottom left-hand corner,

278.text: and if you want that to be a black pixel, you put a 1.

283.text: And then you go to the one above it. And that's black as well, so you put another 1.

286.text: And the one above that is white, so you put a 0.

289.text: The one above that is white; 0.

293.text: 0. Is that two or three? Looks like three. 0. 1. 0.

299.text: And you scroll up the first column, and then up the second column, and up the next one.

303.text: And you write it off as a binary number.

305.text: And you end up, at the very end, with a very long binary number.

309.text: You then put that into base 10.

311.text: You multiply it by 17, and that gives you the k value for where that plot appears on the graph.

318.text: In fact, this is a bitmap function.

320.text: And what Jeff Tupper was doing was looking at using equations and being able to plot them automatically

327.text: using software, he's a computer scientist at the University of Toronto.

330.text: And this is a kind of a side-effect, it's an interesting outcome of the legitimate proper research he was doing.

336.text: In fact, Brady, I got you a present.

339.text: I took the Numberphile logo, pixelated it, turned it into a binary number.

347.text: Put it into base 10. And there it is down there.

349.text: So that is the k coordinate, of the Numberphile logo, on Tupper's plot.

355.text: Okay, so, when I wrote my book, Things To Make and Do in the Fourth Dimension
